010package imagingbook.common.math;
011
012import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition;
013import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.EigenDecomposition;
014import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
015import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
016import org.apache.commons.math3.stat.correlation.Covariance;
017
018/**
019 * <p>
020 * This class implements the Mahalanobis distance using the Apache Commons Math library. No statistical bias correction
021 * is used. See the Appendix G (Sections G.2-G.3) of [1] for additional details and examples.
022 * </p>
023 * <p>
024 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer
025 * (2022).
026 * </p>
027 *
028 * @author WB
029 */
030public class MahalanobisDistance {
031
032        /** The default minimum diagonal value used to condition the covariance matrix. */
033        public static final double DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue = 1.0E-15;
034        
035        /** Used for Cholesky decomposition. 
036         * See {@link CholeskyDecomposition#DEFAULT_RELATIVE_SYMMETRY_THRESHOLD} (1.0E-15), which seems too small). */
037        public static final double DefaultRelativeSymmetryThreshold = 1.0E-6;
038        
039        /** Used for Cholesky decomposition.
040         * See {@link CholeskyDecomposition#DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD}. */
041        public static final double DefaultAbsolutePositivityThreshold = CholeskyDecomposition.DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD;
042        
043        private final double minimumDiagonalValue;
044        private final double relativeSymmetryThreshold;
045        private final double absolutePositivityThreshold;
046
047        private final int m;                                    // feature dimension (length of sample vectors)
048        private final double[] mean;                    // the distribution's mean vector (mu)
049        private final double[][] cov;                   // covariance matrix of size n x n
050        private final double[][] icov;                  // inverse covariance matrix of size n x n
051
052        /**
053         * Constructor, creates a new instance from an array of m-dimensional samples, e.g., samples = {{x1,y1},
054         * {x2,y2},...,{xn,yn}} for a vector of n two-dimensional samples. Uses {@link #DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue} to
055         * condition the covariance matrix.
056         *
057         * @param samples a sequence of m-dimensional samples, i.e., samples[k][i] represents the i-th component of the k-th
058         * sample
059         */
060        public MahalanobisDistance(double[][] samples) {
061                this(samples, DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue, DefaultRelativeSymmetryThreshold, DefaultAbsolutePositivityThreshold);
062        }
063
064        /**
065         * Create a new instance from an array of m-dimensional samples, e.g. samples = {{x1,y1}, {x2,y2},...,{xn,yn}} for a
066         * vector of n two-dimensional samples.
067         *
068         * @param samples a vector of length n with m-dimensional samples, i.e., samples[k][i] represents the i-th component
069         * of the k-th sample
070         * @param minDiagVal the minimum diagonal value used to condition the covariance matrix to avoid singularity (see
071         * {@link #DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue})
072         * @param relSymThr maximum deviation from symmetry (see {@link #DefaultRelativeSymmetryThreshold})
073         * @param absPosThr maximum deviation from positivity (see {@link #DefaultAbsolutePositivityThreshold})
074         */
075        public MahalanobisDistance(double[][] samples, double minDiagVal, double relSymThr, double absPosThr) {
076                if (samples.length < 2)
077                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("number of samples must be 2 or more");
078                if (samples[0].length < 1)
079                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("sample dimension must be at least 1");
080
081                this.minimumDiagonalValue = minDiagVal;
082                this.relativeSymmetryThreshold = relSymThr;
083                this.absolutePositivityThreshold = absPosThr;
084                
085                this.cov = makeCovarianceMatrix(samples, minimumDiagonalValue);
086                this.mean = makeMeanVector(samples);
087                this.m = mean.length;
088                RealMatrix S = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(cov);
089                // get the inverse covariance matrix
090                this.icov = MatrixUtils.inverse(S).getData();   // not always symmetric?
091        }
092
093//      /**
094//       * Create a new instance from the m x m covariance matrix and the m-dimensional
095//       * mean vector of a distribution of m-dimensional data. The covariance matrix is 
096//       * assumed to be properly conditioned, i.e., has all-positive diagonal values.
097//       * @param cov the covariance matrix of size m x m
098//       * @param mean the mean vector of length m
099//       */
100//      public MahalanobisDistance(double[][] cov, double[] mean) {
101//              this.cov = cov;
102//              this.mean = mean;
103//              this.M = mean.length;
104//              RealMatrix S = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(cov);
105//              // get the inverse covariance matrix
106//              this.icov = MatrixUtils.inverse(S).getData();   // not always symmetric?
107//      }
108
109        // 
110
111        /**
112         * Conditions the supplied covariance matrix by enforcing positive eigenvalues on its main diagonal.
113         *
114         * @param S original covariance matrix
115         * @param minDiagVal the minimum positive value of diagonal elements
116         * @return conditioned covariance matrix
117         */
118        private static RealMatrix conditionCovarianceMatrix(RealMatrix S, double minDiagVal) {
119                EigenDecomposition ed = new EigenDecomposition(S);  // S  ->  V . D . V^T
120                RealMatrix V  = ed.getV();
121                RealMatrix D  = ed.getD();      // diagonal matrix of eigenvalues
122                RealMatrix VT = ed.getVT();
123                for (int i = 0; i < D.getRowDimension(); i++) {
124                        D.setEntry(i, i, Math.max(D.getEntry(i, i), minDiagVal));       // setting eigenvalues to zero is not enough!
125                }
126                return V.multiply(D).multiply(VT);
127        }
128
129        // --------------------------------------------------------------
130
131        private static double[] makeMeanVector(double[][] samples) {
132                int n = samples.length;
133                int m = samples[0].length;
134                double[] mu = new double[m];
135                for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) {
136                        for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
137                                mu[i] = mu[i] + samples[k][i];
138                        }
139                }
140                for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
141                        mu[i] = mu[i] / n;
142                }
143                return mu;
144        }
145
146        /**
147         * Calculates the covariance matrix for a sequence of m-dimensional samples, e.g., samples = {{x1,y1},
148         * {x2,y2},...,{xn,yn}} for n two-dimensional samples. The covariance matrix is conditioned to avoid negative or
149         * zero values on its main diagonal.
150         *
151         * @param samples a sequence of m-dimensional samples, i.e., samples[k][i] represents the i-th component of the k-th
152         * sample
153         * @param minDiagVal the minimum positive value of covariance matrix diagonal elements (see
154         * {@link #DefaultMinimumDiagonalValue})
155         * @return the covariance matrix for the supplied samples
156         */
157        public static double[][] makeCovarianceMatrix(double[][] samples, double minDiagVal) {
158                if (samples.length < 2)
159                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("number of samples must be 2 or more");
160                if (samples[0].length < 1)
161                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("sample dimension must be at least 1");
162                RealMatrix S = new Covariance(samples, false).getCovarianceMatrix();    // no bias correction!
163                // condition the covariance matrix to avoid singularity:
164                S = conditionCovarianceMatrix(S, minDiagVal);
165                return S.getData();
166        }
167
168        /**
169         * Returns the sample dimension (M) for this instance.
170         * @return the sample dimension
171         */
172        public int getDimension() {
173                return m;
174        }
175
176        //------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
177
178        /**
179         * Returns the covariance matrix used for distance calculations.
180         * @return the conditioned covariance matrix
181         */
182        public double[][] getCovarianceMatrix() {
183                return cov;
184        }
185
186        /**
187         * Returns the inverse of the conditioned covariance matrix.
188         * @return the inverse of the conditioned covariance matrix
189         */
190        public double[][] getInverseCovarianceMatrix() {
191                return icov;
192        }
193
194        /**
195         * Returns the sample mean vector of dimension m
196         * (see {@link #getDimension()}).
197         * @return the sample mean vector
198         */
199        public double[] getMeanVector() {
200                return mean;
201        }
202
203        //------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
204
205        /**
206         * Returns the 'root' (U) of the inverse covariance matrix S^{-1}, such that S^{-1} = U^T . U This matrix can be
207         * used to pre-transform the original sample vectors X (by X &#8594; U . X) to a space where distance (in the
208         * Mahalanobis sense) can be measured with the usual Euclidean norm. The matrix U is invertible in case the reverse
209         * transformation is required.
210         *
211         * @return the m x m matrix for pre-transforming the original (m-dimensional) sample vectors
212         */
213        public double[][] getWhiteningTransformation() {
214                CholeskyDecomposition cd = 
215                                new CholeskyDecomposition(MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(icov),
216                                                relativeSymmetryThreshold, absolutePositivityThreshold);
217                RealMatrix U = cd.getLT();
218                return U.getData();
219        }
220        
221
222        //------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
223
224        /**
225         * Returns the Mahalanobis distance between the given points.
226         * @param a first point
227         * @param b second point
228         * @return the Mahalanobis distance
229         */
230        public double distance(double[] a, double[] b) {
231                return Math.sqrt(distance2(a, b));
232        }
233
234        /**
235         * Returns the squared Mahalanobis distance between the given points a, b: d^2(a,b) = (a-b)^T . S^{-1} . (a-b)
236         *
237         * @param a first point
238         * @param b second point
239         * @return the squared Mahalanobis distance
240         */
241        public double distance2(double[] a, double[] b) {
242                if (a.length != m || b.length != m) {
243                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("vectors a, b must be of length " + m);
244                }       
245                double[] amb = Matrix.subtract(a, b);   // amb = a - b
246                return Matrix.dotProduct(Matrix.multiply(amb, icov), amb);
247                
248        }
249        
250        // original version
251//      public double distance2(double[] X, double[] Y) {
252//              if (X.length != m || Y.length != m) {
253//                      throw new IllegalArgumentException("vectors must be of length " + m);
254//              }
255//              // d^2(X,Y) = (X-Y)^T . S^{-1} . (X-Y)
256//              double[] dXY = new double[m]; // = (X-Y)
257//              for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
258//                      dXY[k] = X[k] - Y[k];
259//              }
260//              double[] iSdXY = new double[m]; // = S^{-1} . (X-Y)
261//              for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
262//                      for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
263//                              iSdXY[k] += icov[i][k] * dXY[i];
264//                      }
265//              }
266//              double d2 = 0;  // final sum
267//              for (int k = 0; k < m; k++) {
268//                      d2 += dXY[k] * iSdXY[k];
269//              }                                               // d = (X-Y)^T . S^{-1} . (X-Y)
270//              return d2;
271//      }
272
273        /**
274         * Calculates the Mahalanobis distance between point x and the mean of the reference distribution.
275         *
276         * @param x an arbitrary m-dimensional vector
277         * @return the Mahalanobis distance between the point x and the mean of the reference distribution
278         */
279        public double distance(double[] x) {
280                return distance(x, mean);
281        }
282
283        /**
284         * Calculates the sqared Mahalanobis distance between point x and the mean of the reference distribution.
285         *
286         * @param x an arbitrary m-dimensional vector
287         * @return the squared Mahalanobis distance between the point x and the mean of the reference distribution
288         */
289        public double distance2(double[] x) {
290                return distance2(x, mean);
291        }
292
293}
